collectionHeaderMetadata.description: Stories and musings from the Dropbox Design team
collectionHeaderMetadata.title: Dropbox Design

paragraphs.name: e128
paragraphs.text: Dropbox is a big company. Maybe yours is, too. But if I’ve learned anything from this experience, it’s that even a small set of people can influence big changes with the right approach and right temperament. If you have a rational and compelling solution, I encourage you to keep pushing forward. The process isn’t always easy, but the end result is well worth the effort.

At Dropbox, where dozens of teams need to build in lockstep, rapidly launching a redesign without organizational alignment would spell certain disaster. That’s why we had to be persistent and resilient. It would take many months to make our case and align the organization from top to bottom. Resourcing and prioritization would have to be won gradually.
paragraphs.name: ab6b

paragraphs.text: Dropbox is a big company. Maybe yours is, too. But if I’ve learned anything from this experience, it’s that even a small set of people can influence big changes with the right approach and right temperament. If you have a rational and compelling solution, I encourage you to keep pushing forward. The process isn’t always easy, but the end result is well worth the effort.
paragraphs.name: e128
a67e
paragraphs.text: How do you redesign a product built by dozens of teams? How do you convince leaders from multiple teams to commit to a giant project that isn’t on anyone’s roadmap? You might have already read stories about the craft and creative process of holistic redesigns. I want to focus on something a little different: How do you get the organizational support to do a redesign?

aebd98b89c9a.title: Is there anyway to enable this new design if we don’t see it yet?

paragraphs.text: A few weeks ago, we started rolling out our redesign to the world.
Is there anyway to enable this new design if we don’t see it yet?
paragraphs.name: 55ed

a18724d81db4.title: That’s an issue with large organization.

paragraphs.text: That’s an issue with large organization. It takes a compelling and dogmatic spirit to succeed in this.

9bea1921aba4.title: This design is worst than the previous implementation.

paragraphs.text: This design is worst than the previous implementation. Everything is too big and hard to work with. The grid is all over the place, no consistency whatsoever.

e8ea7ac1a83b.title: Great that it unfolded like it did!

paragraphs.text: Great that it unfolded like it did! Unfortunately banks and other companies with restrictive policies have a totally different reality. As a front-end dev in a dept. attached to Sales and not IT I can say that any request submitted to IT is met with a big NO, even if it has gained substantial traction. And those requests are not about doing a fancy…

8a172392a3a9.title: Dropbox is definitely one of the neatly designed products that’s been used by millions of users on…

paragraphs.text: Dropbox is definitely one of the neatly designed products that’s been used by millions of users on a daily basis. However, I’ve always felt that it’s designed for Mac users, because of its low contrast.

249b9b3e48d0.title: Justifying manpower for projects “outside of F17 plan” is nearly as hard as executing them.

paragraphs.text: Justifying manpower for projects “outside of F17 plan” is nearly as hard as executing them. Wonderful to see a larger company investing in exploration teams that end up having a big impact. Kudos.
Yeah, that sounds really tough.

I’ve seen other companies get around something similar by starting a new codebase on the side and not migrating users over until the new thing gets through the checks and approvals. This frees developers to move quickly with new technology while giving them time to work on obtaining permission…

paragraphs.text: Getting stakeholder support for anything is not easy — how much more for a redesign. How long did this entire process take for you? And was it worth all the effort in the end?

14d9d13c4be9.title: Yes! We did all of the above.

paragraphs.text: Yes! We did all of the above. We had quantitative data logged and pulled from our existing website to set a baseline and understand current trends and usage. We looked into customer complaints internally and externally. We conducted usability testing in-house and remotely with prototypes throughout our design process. And we launched the redesign to…

paragraphs.text: This is critical piece of the puzzle. This article reminded us of our experience with a full redesign. Great article!
paragraphs.name: 5cf1

paragraphs.text: Thanks for pointing this out! Accessibility is very important to us at Dropbox. For that reason, we labored to use AA accessible colors for anything that required reading (text, symbols, etc). On the flipside, we only allowed ourselves to use inaccessible colors if the elements were non-necessary. I’m sure there are probably small exceptions but know that we’re logging those as bugs!
paragraphs.name: ab47
